sect1.title: Networking
sect1.para: The Networking panel controls commonn properties related to the ⪚'s presence on its various network interfaces.

sect2.title: External Addresses
sect2.para: The External Addresses Tab, as seen in , lets administrators control how their ⪚ appears to the outside (non-protected) network.

The ⪚ can be set-up to either have a static or dynamic IP address. For a static IP, administrators must configure the network settings as they would for any system on the network. Dynamic addresses are obtained from DHCP.

The interface for configuring these external settings is divided into three sections. The first section determines if the ⪚ is using a static or dynamic address. To choose between these options, the administrator selects either Automatically Set or Manually Set. If Automatically Set is selected, the ⪚ will use DHCP to obtain network settings and display them in the boxes below. If Manually Set is selected, the administrator must manually set the IP Address, Netmask, Default Route (sometimes referred to as gateway), as well as a primary DNS server and a secondary DNS server (optional).
Should Automatically Set be selected, then administrators can optionally request a renewal of their DHCP Lease via the Renew DHCP Lease button. This is the second section as seen in .

Whether Automatically Set or Manually Set is selected for the external interface, the Run Connectivity Test button can be used to perform a test of these settings. This is the third section as seen in . Activating the test will then report its findings (success/failure).

sect2.title: External Address Aliasess
sect2.para: The External Address Aliases tab, as seen in, , is for complex ⪚ deployments.

Use of this feature depends on if the ⪚ is providing NAT services to the internal (protected) network. If running NAT (see ), then this feature can be used to receive traffic for more than just the network of the ⪚'s external interface.

If your ⪚ is not running NAT (sometimes called bridge mode), then each addition to the External Address Aliases will allow ⪚ to route traffic for networks other than that defined by its external IP address.

sect2.title: Hostname
sect2.para: The Hostname Tab, as seen in , configures how the ⪚ may be addresses other than by IP address.

The Hostname tab is divided into two sections, Hostname and Dynamic DNS. The Hostname section lets the Administrator define the hostname of the hostname of the ⪚. The optional Hostname resolves publicly instructs the ⪚ that users on the Internet can use this hostname when connecting to the machine. This is useful when using features such as VPN (see ) or Quarantine Digests (see ) which must embed URLs to contact the machine. When Hostname resolves publicly is checked, such URL will use the hostname rather than IP address of the ⪚.
Note that the hostname entered in this screen is used for generation of the digital certificate for the ⪚ (see ).
The Dynamic DNS tab lets Administrators leverage one of several dynamic DNS providers such that the hostname of their ⪚ will be accessible from the internet.
